content.description: 5.11 climbing with a brutally thin crux around 4th bolt.  This route climbs out the left side huge roof boulder (Please don't climb)
content.location: Beneath the left side of giant floating boulder

content.description: Can't help but smile walking away from this one.  Begin by wrestling out the little roof crack and grab the chossy looking onion jug that feels remarkably solid.  Sustained flake/layback climbing leads to a good crux followed by some more forgiving holds to get a shake from.  Finish on phenomenal face climbing through crimp edges and envelope slots to an amazing view at the chains.
content.location: Walk climber's right until the end of Eastern Prospectors crag.  This wall is recognizable by the bullet hard white/orange stone.  This route begins at a short roof crack in front of a hemlock.  Follows the amazing flake seem up gently overhanging terrain.

content.description:
*There are no quick-links on this route. I have left two draws for convenience of lowering until we get more links in. Please don't top rope on them, and please don't steal them. *** 

 Start in off-width crack and trend left onto the face with the flake. Stand up on top of the flake and trend right under the big block. Climbs moderate (5.8) terrain up to the coyote den ledge where you may or may not have a visitor. Clip the bolt on the bulge and be ready for a series of crimps. Find a hidden edge over the lip on the flatness that will situate you to clip. Mantle up and enjoy the rest of the easy climbing to the anchors.
content.location: Starts in the off-width crack

content.description: Short and vicious bouldering through the first few bolts leads to easier face climbing peppered with a couple surprises that could spit off a snoozing climber. Pretty rock with good climbing but most of the heat is down low.
content.location: Directly underneath the huge floating boulder, shares start with betrayed with a kiss out of the low roof.

content.description: Climb the flake system left of the tree and trend through and right of the tree at the third bolt. Use a flake crimp in the dihedral to stand up to the clipping jug below the mini roof for the fourth bolt. The movement trends straight up for a move then right to an undercling. Find the hidden far right mega jug to clip the next bolt. Follow incredible movement through the entire route!There is an option to clip the anchors as a bolt and mantle up on top of the ledge and use the anchors on Mr Flip Flop to bring a friend up and have lunch with a view. I don't recommend top roping the route off these anchors.
content.location: Starts left of the big black gum tree on a big block into an obvious flake feature

content.description: Bolted by Kylie, this line climbs just right of the chilly cave.  Some stout moves lead to the roof where you have to decide whether to stem or pull really hard.  Not sure if this has been sent.
content.location: right side of the deep chilly cave before the low overhanging roof.

content.description: This one packs some tech punch to get you warmed up for some of the taller gems at EP.  Stick clip. Work up to a hero hold, then to a hidden crimp left of bolt one to mantel the ledge. Head up past pockets on the vertical face.
content.location: 50 feet right of start of cliff. There’s a damp rhodo chocked chimney just right of the route.

content.description: phenomenal flowy face climbing. Once you have the beta on this thing it feels like a dance up a stone wall of edges.
content.location: Far Right of Eastern Prospectors.  Begins on right trending flake chunks into bullet yellow sandstone.

content.description: Stick clip roof bolt with a longer draw and climb the tricky face with to a decent stance before gaining the roof.  Balance your way up to the third bolt and climb to your first rest. Don't forget that this route is giant and take advantage of your rests. Follow the obvious weakness to the top of the orange face and get stoked for chicken head face jugs (and some not-so-jugs) for the second half of the mega climb to the incredible view up top. Make sure your belayer knows that when it seems like you're at the top, you're only half way.
content.protection: 14? bolts + anchors (Bring an extra few, this route is huge)
content.location: Use photo to identify route location

content.description:
Closed project do not climb

 Climbs through obvious weaknesses through several "house of cards" rock stacks (Be aware of potential lose rocks) Move into face crux on good edges before gaining another big flake. Continue up the corner until the "roof" pull on big jugs and finish the route on chicken heads and incredible arete exposure!
content.location: Use route photo to identify route

climbs.name: Much Good Rock
climbs.fa: Kevin Capps, Sasha DiGiulian, Brad Mathisen

content.description: A technical start through beautiful, orange-colored stone leads you into a fun roof maneuver before an easier, but fun finish.
content.location: a few hundred feet past the left turn (or climber's right) in the trail once you reach the bottom of the Prospectors Trails.

content.description: This route maybe looks prettier than it climbs.  Follow the line of bolts through numerous high stepping moves on pretty rock.  The best part of the route is the finish mantle onto a good ledge with an amazing view.  Maybe bring your friend up and have them pack some snacks to hang out on the ledge.  70 meter rope is needed.
content.location: After the big roof the trail  goes down a short hill and behind a small boulder.  This route is just before this boulder.

content.description: A must-do for the grade! Begin with some big moves as you span the reach between the horizontal seams, which can be done if you're shorter. Then, traverse your way out right before executing a punchy sequence as you make your way to the first resting jug on the route. Cop a quick rest before tackling the upper portion of the prow and crimp your way to the chains.
content.location: to the left of a dark, wet cave on a buttress with a prow in the middle of it. This route traverses up and right and finishes on the prow.

content.description: Short, but very good movement and a surprise tricky finish.
content.location: Just right of the crack and before the tunnel/ chimney.  Line of 4 bolts.

content.description: Tricky gear face climbing
content.protection: Lots of smaller gear., 1 bolt + Anchors.  A  .5 Camalot is crucial to protect the final section after the bolt
content.location: Second route on the east prospector climbing trail.  Exits a small roof onto the face.

content.description: This is a quality line that might be perfect for a boulderer looking to climb a hard route with zero pump factor. The crimp crux that greets you at mid-height climbs through amazing stone and has really fun movement, but it is short-lived. The grade on the crux might vary depending on your height and strengths.
content.location: find Make It A Double, this route is the first route to the left of MIAD

content.description: A fantastic moderate trad line. Begin on a crack that turns into two opposing flakes.  Pass two bolts as these flake/cracks end.  Trend right through good horizontal gear and fun holds.  A discontinuous crack picks up again and leads around a small bulge to the top of a small ledge, the anchors, and an amazing view.
content.location: Just before the Eastern Prospector trail flattens out into the "Wish List" area

content.description: Start in jug pocket and make a moves up to good ledges until the mantle towards the top. Find flat sloppish holds and press your way up to the anchors.
content.location: 100 Feet around the corner from Belle of the Ball

content.description: Begin on cobbled rock up to the bulgy arete.  Find amazing pocket jugs trending up and right to a press move.  Finish on classic Breaks perfectly featured sandstone.  Very Fun.
content.location: About 100' climbers right of where the prosepectors east trail begins.  This route climbes the bulgy arete feature climbers right of a crack with a big roof cap.

climbs.name: I thought I Was A Bad Climber Until I Moved Out West

content.description: Begin off the deck following a really cool undercling flake into fun laybacking moves.  Continue up enjoyable face climbing to a good rest.  The finish of the route follows a semi-cryptic crux with smeery feet.
content.location: Far right side of Eastern Prospectors trail.  Just past the amazing line of "Wish List"

content.description: Crack then two bolts. Fun bouldery cruxes.
content.location: Left of Major Tom

climbs.name: House of Cards
climbs.fa: Kevin Capps, Sasha DiGiulian, Brad Mathisen

content.description: A thin slab move down low brings you past some jugs to the top. At about mid-height there is a harder way to do it and an easier way, it may feel more like 5.9 if you choose the harder way, but very fun no matter which way you choose!
content.location: begin just right of Much Good Rock and finishes out a mini-dihedral just left of a large roof.

content.description: Hand jams lead if to a terrific, sequential arete ride past two bolts.  Plug a perfect .5 cam above the bolts, then left for a TCU slot.  Muster some balance to move right to the anchors.  Note; clipping anchors is easier if you climb to final just above them.
content.location: First route at Eastern Prospectors

content.description: Fun chimney to a committing  step across move.  Shares anchors with Major Tom. Pretty unique climbing that makes a decent warm up.
content.location: Start inside the tunnel/ chimney at a low bolt.

content.description: Sweet 100’ gear route with finger buckets and good gear.  Start the same as Belle of the Ball or slightly left of the bolt 1 of Belle, in a hueco.  Crux is right off the ground but you can protect by stick clipping bolt 1 of Belle or use cams to protect bouldery start.  Once even with bolt 1 of Belle, head straight right, then follow buckets to a ledge 60’ up with a short corner crack.  More fun holds and good gear bring you to the top mantle trickery.  When on ledge near top, look up and left for anchors.
content.location: Start on hueco near a trimmed Rhodo, basically the same start as Belle of the Ball

content.description: Nice chimney squirming leads to the top of the pillar, then step across on a nice flake.  Get a small TCU in to protect the mini mantel at the top. Move right to anchors
content.location: Climbs the pillar via secure chimneying.

content.description: Time to feast on some funky movement and variety throughout. Get it! The little wet streak near bolt 2 does not affect climbing.
content.location: Second route right of the Cheers to You corner/ crack.

content.description: Begin on moderate but fun climbing leading up to a good break at the arete prow.  Roll around the arete to a stellar finish that'll leave you wanting more.
content.location: First route climber's left on the wall.  Climbs through the obvious hanging arete feature about 60 feet up.

climbs.name: Family Circus
climbs.fa: Mike Reardon, Alesha Reardon, Joel Fluty

content.description: Finger sized crack start leads to a short white face with amazing holds.  Don’t get suckered into the corner to the right... if you do, there’s still gear and holds but the face is more fun. After face, huck up big holds to a lone bolt, find perfect jug right of bolt. Might still need some scrubbing but great rock!
content.location: Finger sized Crack right of bolt line.

content.description: Still needs a lot of cleaning to make it good.  After that this is an esoteric route that just keeps climbing.  Back clean the first bolt and hang a 24" runner on the roof bolt to reduce rope drag.  A traversing crux mid route will make you ponder and tremble.  After this crux enjoy about 70 more feet of uninterrupted fantastic 5.10 climbing.  Probably one of the biggest single pitch routes at the Breaks
content.location: Middle of the big roof undercut climber's right of the chilly cave.

content.description: Start down left of a gray face in some chunky jug holds.  A small crux leads you back right onto that gray face.  Sustained movement through the face leads to a ledge mid-route.  Take the right face of the arete and crank through big jugs and iron finger buckets toward the point.  A trick reach back around the arete lead to glorious shark fin jugs to the chains.
content.location: Just before the east prospector trail dips down towards the wish list area.

climbs.name: Earn Your Stripes
climbs.fa: Sasha DiGiulian, Brad Mathisen, Kevin Capps

content.description: Climb on beautiful stone as you utilize the perfect crimps and edges on near vertical rock as you climb past the large roof on its right side and mantel over to the anchor.
content.location: Just right of House of Cards, before a large corner where the trail goes back down as you head climbers right.

content.description: Follow the amazing flake feature through really fun layback and undercling movement.  Keep pawing your way up good holds to a jug stance before the last bolt.  Here the route switches styles to sequential reachy face climbing to the chains.  Very satisfying route
content.location: On the buttress right before the cold and wet cave.  The route starts on a dark brown jug and follows the obvious flakey crack feature.

content.description: Great crack with fun features and good gear throughout.  When the crack Peters out above the tree, head right.  Be mindful of the avoidable perched block.  You can get a solid #2 cam before the block and avoid it entirely.  Anchors.
content.location: Second wide crack after passing through the tunnel feature.

content.description: More fantastic features for 90 feet.  If it starts to feel harder than 5.9 search around for hidden iron finger buckets and keep cranking.  Pull the roof to picturesque photo finish.
content.location: Left of Belle of The Ball, starts up and right from a beech-ball sized hueco at chest height.

content.description: Two distinxt crux sequences of different styles. Don’t let the wet start steer you off of this one; it’s easy to work around it.  Begin on shelf to an in cut jug.  Work up to an ear hold past the crack then make a big throw to holds that would make a climbing gym jealous. Continue to a surprising secure dangling flake and pull overlap.  Save a finger tip sized piece for the upper sloped Crux.
content.location: 15 feet right of Feast.  Shares anchors.

content.description: This excellent route begins on the face beneath the roof and trends left around the arete.  Utilize fun movement around the arete leading to a sustained crimpy head wall to the finish.
content.location: About 100' climbers right of the turn onto prospectors east.  Begins climbers left of a crack with a larch roof.

content.description: Don't judge a route by it's name...except this once.
content.location: This route climbs through the juggy looking hanging dihedral.

content.description: Nice arching Crack.  Likely dry in rain.  Anchors under the roof.  Although it looks like it would require large cams at the start, small finger sized slots can be found on the face just left of the Gong flake.  Recommend using the face gear instead of big gear behind the triangular gong flake.
content.location: Arching crack

content.description: Pockets, and balance edges down low lead to a mid way roof, then a final orange headwall crescendo finish.  Note; clipping the second to last bolt is committing but there’s a reason for it.
content.location: Just left of Feast.

content.description: Begin stemming out the dihedral cove to gain the face/crack (otherwise climb dirty slimpers up to the crack)  After gaining the crack follow fun, well-protected easy climbing to a stance beneath the upper arete.  Save a .3/.4 cam to protect this last committing section and mantle to the anchors.
content.protection: Cams + Fixed Anchors.  Save .3/.4 cam for final move.
content.location: First route out of the tiny tunnel on east prospectors trail when heading toward Belle of The Ball.

content.description: Starting in the crack move up and right through good holds. Around the 5th bolt look for a hold in horizontal crack after wrapping around the roof to help you clip next hold. Crux is the last bolt to the anchors.
Good reason to haul out the big cams.  Climb wide crack/ corner to top then move right past bolt and up a small notch, then up past a second bolt and more good gear to anchors.
content.protection: Standard rack including a 4,5,6 cams.  Anchors.
content.location: Obvious corner crack left of It’ll Fish.

content.description: Well protected pulls lead to a sleep move at the bulge.  Just when you think this routes a gimme, it gets tricky techy.
content.location: Between the cracks of Dukes of Hazard and Family Circus

content.description: A fun move out of the little opening bulge allows you to traverse right and into the line proper.  Phenomenal sequential face climbing on perfect stone leads to a committing slopey redpoint move to gain a rest at a stance.  From here the rock quality and movement remains excellent, albeit much easier, to the chains and a great view.  Enjoy!
content.location: Right Route under the enormous dangling roof block 80' up, starts under small roof then traverses back right toward a tree.

content.description: Phenomenal iron finger buckets carve a path through varied features on slightly less than vertical terrain.  Finish at a fantastic roof pull into a good view down gorge at the chains.
content.location: Follow the Prospectors East cliff-line.  After passing through the small tunnel this wall will reveal itself.  Belle of the Ball starts in front of a trimmed rodo with a hueco just right of the first bolt.

content.description: This route surprised me with how fun the climbing was.  Start on straight forward terrain (maybe a bit dusty) leading to the cool bulge features forcing you to think a bit.  Exit on amazing holds with one final little maneuver to the chains.
content.location: Just right of Early Bird, about 30' climber's left of the chilly cave.

content.description: A long wall of great variety- Trad, sport, moderate, harder -climbs.  Late morning sun.
